title: Scots resist Green Investment Bank sale
text:
Xi Jinping welcome defended by Hammond 
Mr Swinney said planned Conservative legislative changes threatened the institution’s focus on green projects and could turn it into “an investment bank like all the other investment banks”. 
He told a fringe meeting at the Scottish National party conference in Aberdeen last week he believed the UK government would need “legislative consent” from Scotland to remove public sector controls on the bank, set up to invest in environmentally friendly infrastructure. 
Such consent is required when UK legislation has an impact on areas of devolved law. Mr Swinney said he had ordered officials to examine assertions it would not be needed in the case of the GIB. “I cannot see how this does not require our legislative consent,” he said. 
Sajid Javid, UK business secretary, announced legal amendments last week to ensure that a privately invested GIB’s operations would no longer affect public sector net debt, which he called a “key objective in moving the company into the private sector”. 
But Mr Swinney said he had not been consulted and criticised the business secretary’s decision to table an amendment without public consultation at the late stages of the Enterprise bill. “This is a big issue,” he said. 
George Kerevan, an SNP member of the Treasury committee, said he understood from the GIB’s management that a sovereign wealth fund had been identified as the preferred bidder for an initial stake, but added he was “adamant” any change to the bank’s status should be blocked. 
The GIB declined to comment on whether Scottish legislative consent was needed but said no preferred investors had been identified. “The sales process has not yet started, but we have been very pleased with early interest shown by a wide range of potential investors following the announcement of the planned capital-raising in June,” a spokesperson said. 
The GIB was set up by the coalition government with cross-party support to address a gap in the market for funding of green infrastructure projects — and that need remained, Mr Kerevan said. In depth

“Everyone agreed it was necessary and the Green Bank has proved it can do that and turn a profit. There is no need to change the model,” added Mr Kerevan. 
Mr Swinney’s warning will add to pressure on the UK government to find a way to ensure the GIB remains focused on green projects and continues to have its headquarters in Scotland after it comes under private control. 
Mr Javid has said privatisation will give the bank access to more capital and is backed by the institution and its board. “The government also wants and expects a privately owned GIB to continue this clear focus on green sectors,” he has said. 
But E3G, a think-tank that advised on the original plans for a green bank, said it seemed destined to compete with, rather than multiply, private investment. 
Sepi Golzari-Munro, E3G senior policy adviser, said: “It was created to help address market failures and to open up major new investment opportunities for private investors in the UK’s low-carbon economy. It remains a mystery how the GIB will fulfil this function under the plans set out.” 
The GIB has already been accused by some investors of acting too much like a typical commercial lender. 
The business department declined to comment on Mr Swinney’s warning but UK officials are understood to believe Scottish consent is not needed for the law change. 
However, Aileen McHarg, professor of public law at Strathclyde university, said it was “incontrovertible‎” that the green purposes included in the legislation related to devolved matters. 
‎Scottish consent would be required for any change that might “have implications for future investment in green technologies”, she added. Related Topics Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015.
